NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
How To Avoid Common Mistakes While Using I-Learn.

 

This article builds on our previous article entitled “What is I-learn good for?”  If you haven’t already read that one, please do.  The Top Five list is a good place to start and includes features that should save you time and make your life easier.  When you feel comfortable with those, then you can move ahead to more advanced features.  Any Learning Management System has its challenges, so here are some suggestions that can help faculty achieve their learning objectives and avoid some headaches. 

 

I-Learn Gotchas fall into three main categories:  1) Grade Center Gotchas, 2) Assessment Gotchas, and 3) General Gotchas.  Since the next two articles in this series deal with Grade Center, this article focuses on General Gotchas and Assessment Gotchas.


General Gotchas


Gotcha #1 – Don’t wait until the first week of the semester to copy your courses:  Perhaps you’ve noticed that I-Learn is sluggish during the few days before and after the first day of a new semester.  That’s because one of the most intensive operations for I-Learn to perform is copying course content. So a good approach is to request new courses well ahead of the next semester.  Then wait until just after the semester ends to copy from an old course into a new.  This lets I-Learn do its copying during a time when fewer users are trying to access it. 

 

Gotcha #2 – Don’t bite off more than you can chew:  Or as King Benjamin advises, don’t run faster than you have strength. Start with the basic features and then move on to the advanced features if they support your learning outcomes.  With these more advanced features, comes a recommendation for training.  There are five great sources of help:

  • Help Desk (3550)
  • The Faculty Technology Center (MCK 355)
  • Satellite I-Learn help centers (Smith 208, Spori 226, and Hinckley 309)
  • Scheduled training workshops
  • I-Learn online tutorials

 

 

 

 

Gotcha #3 – Give your courses descriptive names:  When you request a new course, you are asked to give it a Course Name.  Rather than using something general – like REL 324, or Doctrine & Covenants – use something more descriptive like W09 D&C REL 324 Sec3 KIV.  This enables you and others to quickly locate the right course.

 

Gotcha #4– Don’t use Adaptive Release for tests and assignments:  There are too many ways to mess this up.  There are other ways to allow a student to take a test early or late.  If you need to use this feature, ask for training first.

 

Gotcha #5 – Don’t use I-Learn just because . . . :  The use of any educational tool should make sense instructionally; otherwise, it’s just using technology for technology’s sake.  Hopefully, using I-Learn will benefit you in at least the following ways: help you reach your instructional outcomes, save you time and effort, and help your students learn and teach more efficiently.  If it isn’t doing that, then it may not be worth using. 

 

Assessment Gotchas

 

Gotcha #6 – Don’t select “Open test in new window”:  Most students have pop-up blockers and won’t be able to see the exam. 

 

Gotcha #7 – Don’t select “Hide results for this test completely from instructor and Grade Center”:

This regrettable little checkmark option is found when creating an exam or modifying the test options.  Unfortunately, many instructors miss the warning found right underneath the option.  The key phrase in the warning is “this choice can not be reversed later without losing all attempts.”  No successful workaround has been found and checking this option really does make it so the test responses are completely hidden from the instructor and Grade Center.

 

Gotcha #8 – Create test questions using the Pool Manager instead of the Test Manager:  If you suspect that you may use all or even part of a test again, create your questions in the Pool Manager.  Then use Test Manager to create your test from the Pool Manager.  This will allow you to re-use questions on a future test.

 

Gotcha #9 – Double-check your options before submitting a test:  Make sure the test is available to students and that the availability dates are correct.  Generally, don’t use forced completion.  Don’t uncheck “Include this test in Grade Center score calculations” – the message under the checkbox is self-explanatory.

 

Gotcha #10 – Don’t modify a test after it has started:  This isn’t fair to students, who get different versions of the test.  If you open a test and then notice that something in it needs to be changed, like a typo, you can change it.  But you would want to be sure that your change wouldn’t give subsequent test-takers an advantage over those who took it early. Here are two more important Gotchas that aren’t specific to I-learn, but are directly related:

 

Bonus Gotcha #1 – Don’t give your login info to a TA or secretary:  Some faculty have given their NetIDs and passwords to student TAs or secretaries so they could enter grades or do I-Learn modifications for them.  There’s an easier and more secure way to give them access without compromising your credentials.  To learn how, call the Help Desk or watch the short online tutorial.

 

Bonus Gotcha #2 – Instruct students to call the Help Desk while the problem is occurring:  If students aren’t able to do something in I-Learn (like access a course or submit an assignment), they should call the Help Desk (3550) while the problem is actually happening instead of just emailing the instructor and explaining what happened.  To diagnose the problem, it’s very helpful if the Help Desk agent can ask questions (Are you on campus or off?  Are you on a Mac or Windows computer? Are you using Internet Explorer of Firefox?).  Thanks for reading this article.  We hope you’ll read the upcoming ones on Simplifying Grade Center and Grade Center Gotchas.  If you need additional help, don’t hesitate to call the Help Desk at 3550.
